greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Primes of the form sigma(m^2) where m is a composite number ordered by values m.
comment: All Mersenne primes are here: sigma((2^((p-1)/2))^2) = sigma((2^(p-1)) = -1 + 2^p, for suitable p.
m is of the form p^(2*e) for some prime p and e > 1 as sigma is multiplicative and m is composite. Terms are sorted by values of m. The sequence isn't monotonic. - _David A. Corneth_, Jul 18 2020
link: David A. Corneth, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000 (first 100 terms from Harry J. Smith, terms 101-500 from Amiram Eldar)
example: 19531 is in the sequence as for the composite m = 125 we have sigma(m^2) = 19531. - _David A. Corneth_, Jul 18 2020
mathematica: Do[s=DivisorSigma[1, n]; If[PrimeQ[s]&&!PrimeQ[Sqrt[n]], Print[{n, Sqrt[n], s}]], {n, 1, 20000000}]
program: (PARI) { n=0; for (m=1, 10^9, if (isprime(m), next); x=sigma(m^2); if (isprime(x), write("b065403.txt", n++, " ", x); if (n==100, return)) ) } \\ _Harry J. Smith_, Oct 18 2009

(PARI) upto(n) = {res = List(); forstep(e = 4, logint(n, 2), 2, forprime(p = 2, sqrtnint(n, e), c = (p^(e + 1) - 1)/(p - 1); if(isprime(c), listput(res, [p^e, c]) ) ) ); listsort(res); vector(#res, i, res[i][2]) } \\ _David A. Corneth_, Jul 18 2020
results.author: _Labos Elemer_, Nov 06 2001
ext: Name corrected by _David A. Corneth_, Jul 18 2020
